content:
Nice clash, but could use a couple of edits imo.

1. You don't mention that the level starts at 0, it would be best to explicitly state that rather than leave the clasher to assume it.

2. The part about it being "42" network students is a bit confusing and distracting since the clash is only ever about a single student. It would be easier to understand the statement without that bit. I just got it in a clash and spent most of my solution time just trying to read the statement.

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good work, the problem statement is clear, validators are good 
The trimming part is interesting for a fun clash of code ! 

Tested in python and C++

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Clear problem statement, with appropriate checks
Good job.

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good job
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!
The truncation is pretty sneaky. Overall a good, fun clash problem
good stuff

Cool problem statement. 
Why is the factor mentioned as `0,0075` instead of 75 or 0.0075 using decimal point and not comma as separator, in Equation: `newLevel = previousLevel + 0,0075 * score`. Such minor detail may bother some participants who have paid attention to it.

Also, I suppose the result is not currently "rounded down" but instead it is trimmed to second decimal place. Please update the word in the statement, else people may question the correctness of testcases.

Seems good for solving, and a brisk race for intermediary to experts here üèÅ
A little bit tricky because of rounding, so would fit in beautifully in fastest mode!
Good job
legit clash of code problem. Good Job!

The last two tests are currently not true.
(16*100)*0.0075 = 12.00 != 11.99(as expected in the test).

Also, It would be nice to have some inputs percentage below 50.

Please fix theses 2 smalls things before going live, but I like it.
Not clear why 42 Network students, but the exercise seems good, I see it well in shortest game mode
Maybe it will be better to add scores less than 50% which will not be added to the current level
I've tested it. It's cool

Goal section:
"... curriculum rounded down to 2 decimal places" this is not true. The fractional number is not rounded. It is truncated. I suggest you word it like this:
"Your program should return the final level the student has achieved at the end of the core curriculum using always 2 decimal places."

Solution section:
I think your last test 'Average Student' is displaying a rounding bug that is not coherent with the intention of the game. The result is supposed to be '12.00' instead of '11.99'.

Therefore your solution code has to be fixed. Instead of using '// 0.01 / 1000' which is rounding in a faulty way, use strings to make sure you are truncating the decimal places. I would do it as follows:

num, dec = str(level).split('.')
level_str = num+'.'+str(dec).zfill(2)[:2]
print(level_str)
Very good idea of ‚Äã‚Äãclash nothing to add, I think it would be legitimate to see it in circulation. Upvoted.
haaa that's good I like this exercise

Maybe you should add to your test cases some score below validation to make it more interesting.

Also I think you should say "as input" instead of "in the input"

Goal section
* Please specify that a student starts at level 0.

Input section
* Line 1 description is missing.

Thanks.

Solution:

import sys
from decimal import Decimal, getcontext

getcontext().prec = 6
level = Decimal(0)

N = int(input())
for i in range(N):
    #precise way
    score = float(input())
    level += Decimal(0.0075) * Decimal(score)
    print(level, file=sys.stderr, flush=True)
    #another way
    x = int(level * 10**4) / 10**4
    print("{:.6f}".format(x), file=sys.stderr, flush=True)
    #buggy way
    print(float(level) // 0.01 / 100, file=sys.stderr, flush=True)
    print('', file=sys.stderr, flush=True)

#truncate
num, dec = str(level).split('.')
level_str = num+'.'+str(dec).zfill(2)[:2]
print(level_str)
